main_text:
The term “theory of meaning” has figured, in one way or
another, in a great number of philosophical disputes over the last
century. Unfortunately, this term has also been used to mean a great
number of different things.  In this entry, the focus is on two sorts
of “theory of meaning”. The first sort of theory—a
semantic theory—is a theory which assigns semantic contents to
expressions of a language. The second sort of theory—a
foundational theory of meaning—is a theory which states the
facts in virtue of which expressions have the semantic contents that
they have.  Following a brief introduction, these two kinds of theory
are discussed in turn.
